div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: JUVENILE OFFENDERS.
div.p: The recently issued Report of the Judicial Adviser contains a very interesting section devoted to crimes committed by children and their punishment. During the past year a very marked step in advance has been taken, and it is worthy of remark that a reform which has only been adopted at a very recent date by England and the United States has already been put into operation in this country, and with the most promising results. Among the many pressing social problems few are more important than that of discovering the best way of treating juvenile delir quencies, and of guarding ourselves against the infliction of such penalties as those which, instead of working as corrections, only harden the young offender and turn bim into a babitual criminal. That the Judicial Adviser is fully alive to this possibility is shown by his remark that "it is clear that children who bave once become contaminated by the banefal associations of a gaol are little likely ever to become respectable members of society, but are, on the contrary, after such experiences, more or less inevitably destined to swell the ranks of the criminal classes" And the very fact that this truth is recognised as applying not only to the young, but to the grown-up offender, and that it is now possible for magistrates in England to let a first offence committed by an adult go unpunished, only emphasises the paramount necessity of dealing as lightly, as is consistent with the public safety, with children who have brought themselves within the reach of "the strong arm of the law."

It is, therefore, with great satisfaction that we note the fact of the establishment of Children's Courts in Cairo and Alexandria during the past year. That in Cairo is presided over by Sarwat Bey, the judge in this city being Abdal Fallah Yehis. The Report of the Judicial Adviser deals at length with the Cairo Court, and it also states that the system appears to be working satisfactorily here. The two cities together represent about a quarter of the juvenile misdemeanours and a third of the juvenile contraventions of the whole country, so that a fair estimate of the results of the new system can be based on the experience gained by the two Courts already established. We have little doubt that before long the whole country will participate in the benefits conferred by the new departure, although, perhaps, we can hardly expect to produce such results as those reported from Chicago, where it is stated that the institution of a special court for juvenile offenders has, in two years, reduced the number of boys sent to prison in that city from 1,705 to 20! But if it be true, as stated by Sarwat Boy, that young Egyptians, at any rate in Cairo, manifest but little real tendency to crime, and that they are greatly moved by the advice given them from the Bench, then, there is every ground for hope that a year or two will see the total of 849 cases brought before the Court in 1905, since its establishment on April 6, greatly reduced, if not brought down to infinitesimal proportions. Of the above total, 145 were cases of theft, 269 of assault, 62 miscellaneous, and 418 contraventions, these latter making up nearly one-half of the 849 cases. It is obvious to the most casual observer that it should be easy to reduce the contravention charges, many of them being only for non-observance of administrative regulations relating to various trades, which the authorities would not allow to be passed over, while others were cases of children over 14 years of age who are not by the police regulations allowed to act as shoeblacks. It seems a pity that when drafting such regulations some regard is not had to the question as to what these poor boys are to do if deprived of a chance of earning money in the only way they know how to. They frequently tell the judge that they are without parents or resources of any kind, that they know no other trade and suppose it is better to earn a living if they can, rather than beg or steal. There seems, also, to be wanting better judgment on the part of certain officials in allowing petty charges to be brought before the Court, such, for instance, as the schoolboy who accidentally hurts a comrade at play, or breaks a window in throwing a ball. This same want of judgment is also evinced in many other directions and commented on freely by the Judicial Adviser. As he states that his views are shared by the Procureur General we should not have to wa't long for reform in this direct on.

There are many other sides to this question of juvenile offenders the Reformstory system, State v. voluntary effort, and so onthat we cannot enter apon now, and we must conclude by expressing our conviction that in the establishment of the Children's Courts, a step has been taken that will be productive of great good and leave an indelible mark on he future of Egypt.

div.head: SAMUELSON & SONS
A. & M. SAMUELSON BROS.
div.p: Largest and Oldest Furniture House in Cairo.
Large Stock of Bedsteads, Bed-room, Dining-room, Drawing-room Suites
Curtains, etc., etc., always on Show.

div.head: The Mahmal.
div.p: The Mahmal is expected to arrive at Tor on the 26th inst.

div.head: New Egyptian Company.
div.p: The shares of the New Egyptian Company, Limited, were introduced on the Paris Boarse last week.

div.head: Cairo Flower Show.
div.p: HH. the Khedive will inaugurate the Flower Show at Ghezirah on Saturday next at 3 p.m.

div.head: Popular University.
div.p: This evening, at 9:15 o'clock, the engineer M. Modesse will give a lecture a propos of the Lens catastrophe, entitled "Charbonnages et Grison." Entrance to the lecture will be free.

div.head: Big Land Deal.
div.p: Messrs, Negrib, and Albert Sarsock have sold the Babet Zebra to Youseff Pacha Talaat. This esbet is 2,150 feddane in extent, and is situated in the village of Loukin. The price paid was L E 150,000

div.head: A Tragedy.
div.p: The body of a Turk has been discovered at Abbassieh. The unfortunate man had been struck down from behind by a terrible blow from a loaded cane, which fractured his skull. The police are making enquiries into the case.

div.head: Parricides Exectued.
div.p: Amin Muhamed Mustapha paid the last penalty of the law this morning in the execution-chamber of the Cairo Appeal Court prison for the murder of his father in September last. His brother, who was his accomplice, suffered the same fate yesterday.

div.head: Israelite Choral Society.
div.p: A concert will be given at the New Khedivial Hotel on Sunday next at 9:30 p.m., by the Israelite Choral Society, under the direction of Prof, Marini Simonetti, and with the cooperation of a number of well-known local amateurs. Space does not permit of the publication of the very excellent progamme that has been arranged.

div.head: Asile des Veillards.
div.p: On Monday (St. Joseph's Day) a grand fete was given at the Asile des Veillards at Shoubra unde rthe patrongage of Mme de la Bouliniere. The French Agent and Consul General, M. M. Baroois, Ganem Bay, Privat, Pitelle, P. du Ransas, Gerard, the Countess de Serionne, the Mlles de la Bouliniere, Mlle Barois, Mlle Moures, Mme Sahaar, and Mlle Scharr were present. A sermon was preached by Father Max and a collection in aid of this excellent charitable institution met with the success it deserved.

div.head: Bachelors' Ball.
div.p: The Bachelors' Ball given last night at Ghezierh was well attended and great credit is due to its organizers for the thorough success of the evening. The fine band of the King's Royal Rifle Corps played during the evening and was heard to great advantage, while the excellemt floor and supper provided contributed greatly to the pleasure of the entertainment H. H. the Khedive was graciously pleased to allow his own band to play a programme of music in the garden during the dancing, under the direction of Bimbashi Franklin, Director of Music E. A.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCES.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut-Colonel R.C.C. Cox, commanding, and officers of 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will perform the following selection of music on the Terrace, National Hotel, to morrow afternoon from 4 to 6 pm.
Selection - The Girl from Kay's - Arr Godfrey

By kind permission of Lieut. Col. C. J. Markham and officers, the band of the 1st Batt. King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music at the Ghezireh Palace tomorrow (Friday) from 7.45 p.m. to 8.40 p.m.
III Danse Arabe-IV Danse Russe Trepak
God Save the King THOMAS BROWN Bandmaster.

By kind permission of Lt. Col. Bird and the officers of the R. Dublin Fusiliers the band will play the following programme at the A.S.C. Skye meeting on Saturday- 1 March-Entry of the Gladiators - Fucik

div.head: KAISER'S COMING CRUISE. H. M. AND THE CONFERENCE.
div.p: The Daily Telegraph's Berlin correspondent says that the Kaiser will start on April 3 on his Mediterranean cruise. The correspondent adds that his Majesty is exceedingly anxious to see a successful issue to the Algeciras Conference before the end of March.

div.head: PLAGUE AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: A Berberea groom employed in a stable at Bab Sidra Barrani was found dead on the 19th inst and as the circumstances appeared suspicious his body was removed to hospital and the stable and its neighbourhood were disinfected. Today the bacteriological examination proved that it was a case of plague.
In consequence of this fresh case, the usual prophylactic measures on the departure of vessels from Egyptian ports have been put in force again.

In connection with this case of plague, we have received a complaint that, while the Sanitary Department of the Municipality have whitewashed the base in the district where the case occurred, and taken other similar precautions, they still allow the accumulation of dirt and refuse, injurious to the health, on the open space in front of the stable. We beg to draw the attention of the authorities to this complaint, and trust that the nuisance complained of will be promptly remedied.

div.head: OFFICIAL TRANSFERS
div.p: H. E. Adly Pacha Yaghen, ex Governor of Cairo, took over his new duties to-day as President of the Wakfs Board. The other transfers of governors and mondirs will take place after they have been confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior, in the presence of the Adviser, who arrived in Cairo yesterday evening from Upper Egypt.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive returned to Cairo yesterday evening from Ismailia, where he had been inspecting his estates. To morrow morning his Highness will attend prayers at Abdeen Mosque.

div.head: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYES.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, at its meeting of the 19th inst., decided to forbid any Government employé and functionary to do any salaried work for any private individual or company without the written authorisation of the Minister to whom he may be subject. Infractions of this regulation will be treated as breaches of official discipline.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
div.p: The report of the directors of the Egyptian Mines Exploration Company (Limited) for the year ended December 31 states that crushing was commenced on the Um Ros Mine on March 6, 1905, and the following is a statement of the results since then :- Tons, 6,161. Ounces bar gold 4.295, value realized, £14,721; tons falings stored, 4,895 ; assay value tailings, 3.30 dwt. , and total average yield 17.21 dwt. The properties, now being developed by the subsidiary companies are as follow - Atallah, worked by the Central Egypt Exploration Company (Limited); Semna, worked by the Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Company (Limited), and Eridia, worked by the Eridia (Egypt) Exploring Company (Limited); and the prospects are most satisfactory. Mr. Alford is strongly of opinion that the development on these properties now justify the formation of a company with a working capital of £150,000. He estimates this will be sufficient to build a railway to connect them with Keneh and to erect the milling plant and fully equip the mine. The directors are engaged in negotiations for carrying out these recommendations, and 14 acres of land close to the town of Kereh have been purchased for a mill site.

div.head: UM RUS OPERATIONS.
div.p: The return for February is as follows:- 14 tons of ore were rushed, 390 ozs bar gold were introduced , valued at £1,337, 411 tons of tailings have been of an average assay value of 3 dwts per ton. The mill ran 15 days of 24 hours.

div.head:
THE AKABA AFFAIR.
H.H.S. AIDA RETURNS.
SHIPS THAT PASS IN THENIGHT.
div.p: H. H. S. Aida arrived at Suez from Akaba on Tuesday.
On Sunday last, at 11 o'clock at night, a Turkish trade port with troops was seen storming into Akaba, but it is not known yet whether she landed any troops.
The Aida will sail again for Akaba on the 27th inst.

div.head: THE AMERICAN SQUADRON.
div.p: The American Squadron will leave Alexandria next Monday forencon.
Rear Admiral Sigebee and the senior officers of the squadron will be entertained to dinner at Cairo by H.H. the Khedive on Saturday next.

div.head: AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: The Austrian Squadron will remain here for over two weeks. There will be a ball on the Admiral's flagship Habsburg and the S. George on the 5th April. There will be 1,300 guests. This morning Rear Admiral Jedios paid an official visit to Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria and Rear Admiral Sir Massie Boomfield.
The Austro Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo to visit the Admiral. A number of officers of the squadron went to Cairo to-day for a visit.

The squadron contains some of the best vessels in the small but efficient navy of the Emperor Francis Joseph. The Habsburg, Arpad, and Babenburg are extremely handy little ironclades, displacing some 8,400 tons. Their designed horse-power was 18.5 knots, which all exceeded averaging 19.6 knots on their trials. Their protection, if not equal to that of the largest British and French battleships, is efficient, the belt being 8 ¾ inches thick, while the turrets are protected by 9 ¼ inch armour. The armament comprises three 9.4 inch and twelve 6-inch guns, with ten twelve-pounders and ten machine guns. The St. Georg is a new armoured cruiser with a speed of 21 knots and a displacement of 7,400 tons. In her case, coal capacity, which is of slight importance to Austrian vessels whose radius of action must be limited in case of war to the Adriatic and the Levant, has been sacrificed to protection and gun power. She carries two 9.4 inch, five 7.5 inch, and four 6-inch guns, with seventeen smaller pieces and two submerged torpedo tubes and is for her size one of the best armed warships afloat.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Under the provision of the Ottoman Order in Council (1905), the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs has appointed Mr. William R.B. Buscoe, barrister-at-law, to the office of Crown Prosecutor in H.B.M Consolar Court for Egypt.

div.head: THE WADY RAYAN
div.p: The latest American newspapers to hand contain the following news item: -

Washington. The Department of State has confirmed the assertion of Cepe Whitehouse of Newport, that he made application in Egypt in due form to take title to a vast tract of desert land in the latter country, including the site of an ancient city which he discovered. His claim has been held up in the Egyptian Foreign Office.

div.head: NAZIM PACHA'S "PROMOTION."
div.p: There can be no doubt that Nazim Pacho has been promoted" from the post of Governor of the Vilayet of Damasons to that of acting Governor of the island of Rhodes. The Commander of the 5th Order, Kiszim Pacha with the Chief of Police, the Deterdar, and several other prominent officials, have received notice of their transfer to less highly paid and important posts, and great regret is expressed at the departure of an honest and just Governor and of several capable officials. Of Nazim Pacha's successor, Shukri Pacha, little is known, nor is it yet decided who will command the Syrian Army Corps.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ADVERTISING COMPANY
div.p: A new Egyptian company has been founded under the title of the "Société Anonyme Egyptienne de Publicité" by the undermentioned gentlemen, who have subscribed the following number of shares each -

Max Fischer. 2.000, E. Del Mar 100; R. E. Fischer, 100, Gustare Hugar 50, Boris Ehrlich, 50, Siegfried Fischer, 101, Ernest Huffar, 100. The capital consists of 2,500 shares of £E4 each, and there are also 2,500 founders' shares. The objects of the company are officially declared to be as follows:
La Société a principalement pour objet la publicité sous toutes ses formes, en Egypte et ailleurs, et tous actes ou opérations a'y rattaobant directement ou indirectement.

Elle pourra également s'occuper de toute affaire pouvant contribuer au développement de l'objet de la Société et notamment faire tous achats et veits de marchar diren et objects bar que're ques pouvant se rattacher à l'objet de la Société
Elle pourra s'associer ou se fusionner refondre d'autres entreprises similaires, acquérir ou les auvexer.

div.head:
CHILDREN'S COURTS.
JUDICIAL ADVISER'S REPORT.
SOME INTERESTING EXTRACTS.
div.p: We give a few extracts from the Judicial Adviser's Report, dealing with the establishment of Courts for the trial of juvenile offenders:

For some considerable time past it has been becoming more and more evident to the authorities that far too many young children are sent to prison in Egypt. Not that Egypt presents a peculiar spectacle in this respect, for the same the phenomenon is unhappily observable in most countries, and is everywhere proving a force of anxiety to legislators and prison reformers. And it obviously is a matter of the first importance. One of the principal aims of modern two penologists is, as far as possible, to cut off the sources of criminality at its toes, and it is clear that children who have once been contaminated by the baneful associations of a gaol are little likely ever to become respectable members of society but are, on the contrary after such experiences, more or less inevitably destined to swell the ranks of the criminal classes.

As far as this country is concerned, it must be admitted that this unsatisfactory state of things was largely due to the defective condition of the law, before the revision of the Penal Code. The old article 58 drew a highly theoretical and highly artificial distinction between the case where the child was supposed to have acted "with discernment" and those where he had not. In the former case the judge was bound to convict and to sentence the offender to fine or imprisonment. He had no power to send him to a reformatory. That course was only open to him if he found that the child had acted without discernment, in which case he had to acquit, but might, nevertheless, if he thought proper, send the boy to a reformatory. Of course, in practice, the proof of discernment or its absence was always difficult, and some judges habitually took one view and some another, which led to very unsatisfactory results. The new law, therefore, swept away the whole of this on cumbrus and factitious doctrine and gave the judge a very wide discretions to the penalties he could inflict, if he found the young offender guilty of the act with which he was charged.
In cases of crime or misdemeanour he can either :
(1) Sentence to imprisonment or to fine when permitted ;
(2) Hand the child over to his parents or guardian on certain terms ;
(3) Order him to be whipped (this in the case of boys only) ;
(4) Send him to a reformatory for from two to five years ;
(5) Order him to be whipped and then sent to a reformatory.

Having thus effected a considerable improvement in the law, the next thing was to endeavour to provide some special machinery the for its effective application, and it appeared to me that this might very possibly be successfully accomplished by essaying here the system of Children's Courts, or Courts reserved special for juvenile offenses and presided over by a special judge, which has given such excellent results in other countries. As is well known, the system is in force in America, in Australia and other of our colonies, in Scotland and in certain parts of England and Ireland, e.g., Birmingham, Bradford, Dublin and Cork. It was accordingly decided to try the experiment of such a Court in Cairo, inasmuch as there did not appear to be any prima-facie reasons for supposing that it was, in any way, unsuited to an oriental country, and the system was subsequently extended to Alexandria.

Young Egyptians, at any rate in Cairo, manifest but little real tendency to crime. In the majority of the cases brought before me. there was no ground for the belief that the instinct of these offenders towards criminal misconduct was such as to justify a heavy and severe punishment in order to correct them. On the contrary, I found that in most cases, by reproving them severely and pointing out to them the inevitable consequences of the course they were pursuing, they were greatly moved. I am glad to be able to say that the method in which I followed in explaining to them that whereas I was indulgent to them for the first time, they need expect nothing but pitiless severity if they transgressed again, has had the effect of preventing almost all those who have come before me from committing further offences.

Obviously the parents of juvenile offenders are often responsible. I always took the opportunity of the presence in Court of the young offender's father or guardian to give him sound advice as to watching over the conduct of his child--and this not only in times where I decided to hand over the offender to his parents, but even where in view of the comparative gravity of the offense, I ordered him to be whipped.

In working at this Children's Court, I have not confined myself solely to the decision of the cases put before me. I have endeavoured to influence the action of those who are responsible for dealing with cases in which juvenile offenders are concerned.

I am, however, far from saying that cases of juvenile offenders in Cairo are now dealt with in an entirely satisfactory manner. There is still much room for improvement. Such cases should be far less numerous than they are at present, and many of those who are now brought up as accused persons before me should never have been committed for trial at all. I still notice that cases are submitted to the Court which are of a very trifling nature and ought therefore to have been filed. ln others it is adult persons who are principally concerned ; the juveniles being merely implicated through filial affection or similar motives and should not have been put upon their trial. For instance, two families quarrel with one other. The son or daughter, seeing their father or mother being assaulted, attacks the other party or insults him. The son or daughter is considered by the police to have taken part in the quarrel, and is consequently prosecuted. The case comes up to the Juvenile Offenders Court and one observes that all the accused are grown-up men or women, with a young boy or girl, tried with them, because they have attacked or affronted the assailant of their parent. Before concluding, I desire to call attention to three points:

First, the necessity of enlarging the Reformatory and increasing its accommodation. From time to time I receive an intimation from the proper authorities that no more boys are to be sent to the Reformatory, owing to its being quite full and there being no vacancies. In some cases, however, a reformatory sentence would, having regard to the offence committed be the only suitable penalty. Cases have also come before me in which young girls were accused, where the facts of the case and the position of the offenders' parents were such to render a Reformatory sentence by far the most suitable of all those which might be inflicted. But the fact that there is no place for girls in the Reformatory has prevented the pursing of such a ganter, and other penalties had to be inflicted. The power of the judge not being so wide in the case of girls as in the case of boys, it is desirable to take steps, as soon as possible for the addition to the Reformatory be of a section for girls.

Secondly, the institution of industrial schools to which children could be handed over, if an guilty of light offence, whether misdemeanours or contraventions (such as, for example, cases of mendicity and contraventions against the regulations as to the various trades). In many cases, the position of the offendere renders it necessary, if they are to be reformed, that they should not be a burden to their parents nor be left to wander about the streets, homeless and neglected.

Thirdly, the desirability of organizing some authority to which parents may apply for the correction of their children. The feeling of satisfaction with which the people hailed the institution of the special Juvenile Offenders Court, as an indication that the Government was interested in the welfare of the young, and their readiness to have recourse to it whenever their children gave them cause for complaint, has been extremely remarkable. All classes of the population regret the failure of the Native Codes to sanction paternal rights and power, as in French law (articles 376 & 377 of the Civil Code), which enables the father to have his unruly child incarcerated for a month or six months, according to circumstances. Personally, I am strongly in favour of granting such powers to Mohammedan parents, many children being nowadays so undisciplined as to be practically incorrigible by any other means. Of course the place of confinement should be a special establishment.

I fully agree with the remarks of Sarwat Bey as to the want of judgement displayed by certain officials in the taking up of petty cases. Such matters as some of those to which he has called my attention, where young schoolboys are prosecuted for accidentally hurting a comrade at play, or for breaking a window with a ball, are obviously of too innocent a character to be brought before a Police Court.

But the fact is that it is not only in the case of juveniles that we are suffering from an excess of zeal on the part of some officials. The same want of judgment is noticeable in the case of petty assault(coups) and insults (injures) of which a vast number are of so trivial a character, if genuine at all, that the Police should decline to prosecute and leave the complainant to do so himself, if he thinks fit. This has, I know, long been the opinion of the Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior and is a matter to which he has repeatedly called attention. And as these views are also shared by the Procureur General, I hope that before long a solution, or at any rate palliative may be found.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Heaton Armstrong, M.P., who sails for Europe tomorrow, returned to the Savoy yesterday after visiting the Corporation's concession in Upper Egypt. He expressed himself as being thoroughly satisfied with the progress made and the Corporation's future.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mass Liner Rameses arrived at Liverpool Today.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the passengers who left for Europe yesterday by the North German Lloyd Schleswig were Lord Morley, Sir George and Lady Cooper, Vicomte de Gironde, Saba Pacha, Consul-General Hartmann, Mrs. Leigh Hunt, Mr. Fred. Morgan, Mrs. Macpherson Grant, Baron von Steiger, etc.
Peake Bey, Assistant Postmaster General, will act as Postmaster General during the absence of Saba Pacha, who is not returning to Egypt until the 1st June.

Baroness Rucker Jenisch left Cairo yesterday morning to join her husband at Berlin. Many friends of the Baroness, among them all the chief members of the German colony, were present at the station to say farewell to the wife of the German Diplomatic Agent at Darmstadt, who, like her husband, leaves none but the pleasantest souvenirs.

Count Bernstorff, who has been appointed to the German Embassy in Egypt, will be succeeded in London by Herr Wilhelm von Stumm, who comes from the Madrid Embassy. He belongs, the Berlin correspondent of the Glasgow Herald says, to the great industrial family of that name, of which the head was Baron Karl von Stumm-Halberg, the notable German ironmaster and pillar of the Conservative Party in the Reichstag. A. Baron von Stumm left only a daughter, the elder line died out, and the new secretary of the London Embassy is now the head of the family. It is only five years since the great firm Stumm celebrated its 200th year of existence. In March. 1701, "Stumm the Smith," as the chronicles fame him, founded the firm which now enjoys a world wide reputation.

Sir Ernest Cassel is having extensive alterations carried out at Brook House, which are not expected to be completed until the end of the summer, when Sir Ernest, who is at present on the continent, will take up residence there.

The late Mr. Wilberforce Bryant, D.L., J.P., of Stoke Park, Stoke Poges, Bucks, Chairman, and son of the founder of the well-known match manufactory of Messrs. Bryant and May's and a director of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, who died on February 3 last, left estates of the value of £18,155 gross, and £73,804 net.
Mr. John R. Gubbin, whose death is announced by Reuter to-day, was a well-known patron of the Turf and owned some famous mounts. He first important win was in 1870,

when he won the Devonshire Plate riding Mr. J. D. Whyte's Fairyland. He was also the winner of the Weller Cup at the Down Royal Meeting in 1883, and in 1897 achieved success with Galtee More, winning the Two Thousand Guineas and the Derby and the St. Leger. In 1902 he won the Darby with Ard Patrick.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice : Lady and Miss Kitson, Mr Montgomery, Mr. Bence, the Hon. Mulholland and party, Capt. Taylor, Senor De Ory and family, Mr. A. Rickwood, Mrs. Orgill, Mrs. Kirby, Mr. Stepheno Eadie, Mr. Jones Vaughan, Mr. and Mrs. Peacock, Mr. L. H. Rickards, Dr. and Ms. Pain, Mr. Higgins, Mr Percy Shepherd, Mr. and Mrs. Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Charrington, Mr. B. C. Hubbard, Mr. Sameson, Mr. Mansfield, Rev. Cooper, Rev. Taylor, M. Crawford, Mad. Pilas, Mr. Waterlow.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. R. Williams, Gen. and Mrs. Lanca, Mr. A. E.T. Sarfas, Mr. and Mrs. D. M. Dunlop, Mr. G. A. Wheatley, Mr. N. C. Barker, Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Aldis, Misses E. and G. Aldis, Mr. and Mme Nayt, Mr. and Mrs. Colbourne, Mr. A. Temon, Mr. G. J. Demetralis, Mr. W. Went, Mr. M. H. Bulley, Mr. Peacock, Mr. Malcolm, Miss Dresser, Miss Francis, Mrs. Malcolm, Mr. J. A. Afriat, Mr. A.M. Johnson. Dr. and Curling Hayward, Mr. de Behmout, Mrs. Larsen, Mrs. A Hang, Mr. T Theodorides, Mr. Th. Mittmann, Mr. Ed. S. Grech, Mr. M. de La Valette, Dr. Alex Roesle, Mr. W. Klose.

div.p: In connection with the Karoon Hotel Fayoum.
For particulars apply Mr. TASCO, Fayoum.

div.p: The reputation which these Cigarettes have gained in the past, stands unrivalled today, because it is well-known that constant care and attention is devoted to supplying treally first-class Cigarettes only.
Between the Bristish Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head:
ALGECIRAS
RUSSIA'S ATTITUDE.
AGREEMENT CONCERNING POLICE.

div.p: The "Tempa" says that Count Lamadorff has telegraphed to the Russian delegate at Algeciras denying the German Press reports that Russia is sympathising with the German proposals and declaring that Russia is always France's faithful ally. (Reuter)
An agreement has been come to as regards the powers of the officers entrusted with the organization of the Morocco police. (Havas)
The Moorish Pretender has addressed a letter to the delegates at the Conference declaring that he is the true Sultan. (Reuter)

div.head:
TRANSVAAL LABOUR QUESTION.
NO NEED OF COMMISSION.

div.p: House of Commons - During the debate on the Appropriation Bill, Mr. Chamberlain moved that a Royal Commission should be appointed to investigate the labour question in the Transvaal. Mr. Winston Churchill said that the appointment said that the appointment of a Commission was both unnecessary and futile and whatever its decision might be, one side would remain unconvinced. The motion was rejected by 378 to 110. (Reuter)

Mr. Lloyd George's Bill excludes the employment of foreign seamen who are unable to understand the English words of command, and contains a number of provisions for improving the condition of sailors. (Reuter)

div.head:
FORMOSA EARTHQUAKE.
THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE KILLED.

div.p: It is estimated that several thousands of persons were killed in the earthquake in Formosa. Three towns were destroyed and the whole island was shaken. (Reuter)
Conflicts are taking place between the gendarmes and riotque strikers at Lene (Reuter)
Mr. John R. Gubbins, owner of Galtremore and Ard Patrick, is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: SUDAN SPECULATION.
div.p: A correspondent writes as follows to the "Sudan Times". -

A sense of distrust of the foreign merchant seems to permeate the atmosphere of the Government circles. To most Government officials merchant and speculator are synonymous and little sympathy is felt for either. The interests of the merchant class and the natives are supposed to be diametrically oppossed. In its eagerness to win popularity among the Sudanese the Government spares no effort to secure what is believed to be protecting them from the greedy foreigner.

The merchant makes money in the dura trade. At once measures are suggested for putting and end to "speculation" and "cornering". He buys land and the cry is raised that he is robbing the natives of their inheritance and that such trespasses should be vetoed in the interests of the natives and the country generally. He offers to lend money at interested and he is dubbed "naurer" In fact one hears nothing else but talk of naury, speculation, and all the other time worn terms which signify nothing but lack of insight into the natural course of things.
It is amusing to read the crude suggestions made by some officials to stern the tide of these evils and keep the Sudan spotless.

As a merchant my words may not carry much weight, but time and time alone will show the fallacy of the truth of my intentions. This is that so long as the Sudan Government does not provide ample room for private enterprise and does not renounce the antiquated system of interference with all things, the progress of the Sudan, will be very slow indeed. Many of those who visited the country this winter with a view to extending their operations into it went away with a different conviciton.

div.head: DISCONTENTED EMPLOYES.
div.p: The following is the text of a "reclamation" (as it is termed), which has been sent to the chiefs of the State Railways by the Traffic pupile of the Railways. -

Sir:= It is said that as the chief is greater the justice and mercy, the greater is the rest of his employees and as long as compassion and right are his conduct, they may ask for their due of which they have been deprived and neither small or large crime they won, nor any guilt they have committed.

We are aware, you are a good experienced man who knows well the miserable condition of the Railway Employees specially those of the Line Department. They deak great trouble in their works either at day-time or during night whether at winter in the very coldest places or in the deserted stations where there cannot be found the necessary livelihood affairs moreover they work barely without any season leave. Should the Adm. authorize the one of them any annual leave, it does not increase 7 days, and bondest to this greatest hardheartedness and the ill treatment of the case of oppression, the paucity of salaries is added.

This wretched and lamentable case, to which we are all crying and grieving too much, obliged many of the employees to resign, to live freely in draught and famine than to serve as they are the batter enemies of the Adm. and not its faithful employees who serve it literally and sincerely.

Do you think that such statement of the Traffic Pupils (specially) satisfy any? We think you are very sorry for such condition, the hardest heart of which justice, the care, and the blind eyes weep bitterly.

What do you mean by serving hardly by a daily payment of 15 P.T., the earning of shoe-blackmen or a low servant at day and remain hors cadre a period not less that 5 years. What is the use of our useless certificates that we have lost their meaning in our loved Adm. for it's irregular treatment which is inconsistent with Financial Code and Governmental Decrees.

Did not all resignations attract your attention to know why they have taken place or did not this loud cry strike your kind ears to rectify our bad case to another of which you will be met by the heartly thanks of all oppressed poor men who deserve assistance. What will take place, do you think, should we are treated as all employes in all Adm. and do you lose if your support and help us?
You are celebrated by the moralities and the good deeds, but we have unfortunately seen nothing of them towards us for nothing of such complaints has been communicated to your kindness.
We hope that you will soonly grant us the following demands; the one of which is o the vital importance towards us -
(1) To vanish the function of Traffic Pupil by a term Relieving Traffic Assistants.
(2) To commence salaries by L.E. 6 monthly instead of the bad case of the daily payment treatment.
(3) To grant us the season leaves according to the Decrees as in all Gov. Adm.
(4) To rectify our period in the Adm. according to [augmentation and cadre as in Govt. Fin Code.]
(5) Not to be conencted with the vacancies of the Adm. in view to the augmentation, but the salaries must be augmented in the yearly budget as long as the employed is deserved.
(6) The travelling allowance must not be less than 20 P.T. a night.
(7) To dwell in the houses of the Administration freely such as Station Masters, Perm Inspectors, Telegraph C. in C., Point men, Gattis, etc., as the case was before.
We hope, Sir, that all our demands will be taken into considerations and that they will meet your kindness with approval,

div.head: Khedivial Mail Line.
div.p: The Kedvidial Mail Steamship "I-mailia" will be despatched from Alexandria on Monday, April 16th for Pirsces direct, and should sufficient passengers offer, the vessel will make a second trip from Alexandria on Friday April 20th.

The vessel will return from Pirsces on the conclusion of the games on Thursday, May 3rd, but holders of return tickets will have the option of returning by the Company's mail steamer of April 26th, should they so desire.
(A reduction of 25 on the fares (excluding cost of food) will be allowed to holders of "bonestifs" of the Olympian Games Committee)

During the stay of the vessel as Pirsces from April 22nd to May 3rd, first and second class passenger will be allowed to sleep on board on payment of P.T. 50 per day first class and P.T. 40 per day second class, which will include meal, but notice of daily meal prepared must be given one day in advance to the Chef Steward.
Early application for accommodation should be made to the Company as those in Alexandria, or to the principal Tourist Agencies.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The General Administration of the Wakfa informs the public that it possesses at Alexandria lands of a superficial of about 18 feddans situated on the bank of the El Farkha Canal, which fetched at the last adjudication the price of I.E. 24,500.

The Superior Board of the Wakfa Administration having ordered the sale by auction of the said lands by way of exchange, the Administration will receive offes on Sunday, 29th April, 1906 from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., at the offices of the Wakfa Administration Babel Loul, Cairo, for the renewal of the auction above mentioned.

All persons wishing to take part in this appradisestion may see the lists of bids at the office of the Administration and make an offer, which must be accompanied by 20% of the total amount in ratio to the above price.
The Administration reserves the right to refuse of accept anu offer, without giving the reason.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
The Money Market.
div.p: The decline in the American exchange and the weakness in the French rate mentioned in this column last week have had the effet looked for, and weekly loans now command 3, whilst discount rates have hardened to 3 for three months' bills. Gold having been shipped from San Francisco to Tokin, and some purchases of the precious metal having been made here on American account, caused some uneasiness and attracted more attention than the circumstances warranted. The exchange not having receded to a figure which could make the shipment of the gold in question a profitable transaction from an arbitrage point of view, it was no doubt undertaken in the interest of some Stock Exchange operations. The rate of exchange has since been recovered; it now stands at 4.86 (cable) and it is rot anticipated that any serious drain of gold to that country will take place in the immediate future.

The French exchange, however, has shown marked weakness during the past few days, having declined 1 points, and to-day, at 25.13, it as a menace to our gold reserve. To the Morocco Conference must the present uncertainty be mainly attributed. Could a settlement be arrived at, the atmosphere would at once be cleared, French money would flow into our markets, and the relief felt would be almost instantaneous, but this happy state of things cannot be hoped for in the next few days, as is expected in some quarters.

One leading factor which tends to keep money and discount at such a high level is the collection of revenue. The amount of public deposits is now over 19 millions, which is higher than it has been for some years past, and the commerical community is justified in grumbling and demanding that something should be done to obviate this difficulty.

Apart from the disclosure of the above fact, the Bank returns this week are not very interesting. "Other Deposits" show a slight decrease, and "Other Securities" an increase of about half a million, not withstanding that many bills must have matured during the period covered by the returns.

The Stock Exchange has this week simply been a relfection of the position at Algeciras, alternately buoyant and depressed, and with the exception of the large traffic returns of the South American railways and some specially favourable news for the shareholders of the Peking Syndicate, there has been nothing worthy of note.

The Kaffir market continued to receive blow after blow from the repeated and extraordinary utterances of Mr. Winston Churchill, developing the views of the new Government in the direction of the proposal new self-governing colony. That the heavy losses in the mining shares have fallen on a very large number of small investors, and have been to the advantage of the larger groups, who were apparently aware of the policy of the Government beforehand, there is little doubt. At the same time the practical outcome is not likely to be as bad as the pessimists forecast. In the meantime the Kaffir market becomes a heavier burden each account.

In common with other stocks, gilt-edged securities have been very dull throughout the week, with a daily decline in the price of Console, which yesterday changed hands as low as 90 for cash. They are now a little firmer and close at 90 for cash and 90 for the account.

The features of the market for international bonds in the early part of the week was the strength of Russian Fours, which were largely bought as the result of rumours of a new loan. The price jumped a full point to 85, and this was when a fall of 1/2 was registered. The quotation to-night is 84 3/4. Some of the Japanese stocks have also been in demand, especially the Four-per-cents, which on Wednesday were 5/8 higher than our last quotation at 90 7/8. They are now 90. The second series of sixes are better at 10 1/2.

There has been very little business done in home railways since our last, and this can only be accounted for by the general weakness of markets, for the traffic returns this week are better than ever. The North Eastern have an increase of over $11,000, and the North Western of $10,000 while there are several four figure gains. The slight improvement in business noted on the publication of these results has been surrendered, and the market is now dial in the extreme.

A has prevailed in the American market, which has been acting in close sympathy with Wall Street. Prices all round are somewhat below last week's level, with the exception of Louisvilles, which have risen 2 3/4 points and Illinois Central, which are 1 3/4 up, in good buying. The closing prices in the leading Americans are as follows -

Arkansas, 96 1/18, Baltimore 113, Caradis Pacific 194 1/4, Chicago and Milwaukee 18 1/2, Erie 43 3/4, Illinois Central 17, Louisville 154 1/9, New York Central 135, Petryvaniansh 70 3/4, Philadelphia and Reading 6 3/4, Southern Pacific 68 1/4, Union Pacific 15 5/8, Steel Common 41 11/18. Steen Preference 108.

The Egyptian Market has been quiet, but very firm during the past week and serveral shares are higher on balance National Bank of Egypt are up to 28 3/5, Agricultural Banks are quoted ex dividend of 6, and close 9 10, the new shares being now the same price. Diara Senieh Ordinary have been in demand, and finish at 18 1/2 buyers. The deferred are unmentioned at about 105. New Egyptians are also good, and have been largely bought, closing at the top 1 3/4 7/8. Delta Land and Investment are up to 3 1/2 3/4, and Delta Preference Bearer are bid for at 12 5/18. Khedivial Mail have been left alone, and are nominally 2 3/4 the preference being 4 3/5 7/8. Land Bank of Egypt have been up to 9 closing at about 8 3/4. Corporation of Western Egypt at 13/18 and Union Fosciere at 6 1/2 are unchanged. Egyptian Estates Ordinary are still firm at 2 1/8. There has been a large demand for the Deferred shares, but there were none to be procured. The price of these is now 13 1/8 14. Eight Deferred shares were offered at 14, but were withdrawn.

Bank of Abyssinia close 3/8 premium. There has been further steady buying of Bank of Roumania, the price rising to 10 1/8 - 3/8, but there are very few shares about, and it takes very little to move the price. It is difficult to see how the shares can be worth so much. Daira Sugar are about 4 1/2.
Depression previals throughout the South African market, and prices all round are marked still lower. Rand Mines have fallen 7/18 to 5 3/18. East Rands 3/8 to 4 3/18, and Goldfields 13 32 to 4 17 32.
Of the Egyptian section, there is little to report. Nile Valleys have continued the seesaw movement, and close a little higher on the week at about 4/9.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: Egyptian cotton on the spot has been very neglected, and quotations of Brown are reduced 1/8 per lb., and Upper 1/18 per lb. In Futures a moderate business has been done, and the latest quotations are delivery: -

American Futures The Market this week has again been narrow with frequent fluctuations, but in the absence of any speculative disposition, prices have had a declining tendency, to-day's closing values veing 10 @ 11 points below those of last Thursday. There is no special features. There has been continued liquidation, chiefly in the American markets, where apparently some stale "Bull" accounts have been thrown over, and the buoyant demand by spinners has been a little less in evidence. As far as we can learn the prospects are for an increased planting, work well forward, and a considerable use of fertilizers reported. It is, however, much too early to base any argument upon these points, only, when other conditions are absent, they exert a certain influence.
The general weather conditions are unchanged. The barometer is steady.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: Attendu que la véritable question litigieuse dono de voir si la préemption actuelle tre dans l'un des cas de préemption licite vus par l'article 1 N 2 du Décret sur l'asSomption du 26 Mars 1900.

Attenda que la loi exige comme condition d'admissibilité de la préemption, entre voisine, I s'agit d'immeubles ruraux, que les terrains ient contigues des deux côtés et que la valeur celui du préempteur représente au moine la pitié de la valeur du terrain préempté ($ 3 de it. 1 N° 2); Qu'il est d'autre part constan' entre les parties et d'ailleurs établi & priori per documents de la Case que cette double condition n'existe pas en l'espèce en sorte qu'il y a lieu de rechercher si l'espejo rentre dans l'une des deux autre hypothèses légales est à dire s'il s'agit d'immeubles urbains, de loi s'entend de "constructions on terrains des néz à être bâtis, situés dans une ville ou dans • village" (8 1 de l'art. 1 N 2) on s'il s'agit 'immeubles reliés par un rapport de servitude (1 de l'art. 1 N° 2); auxquels cas la loi 'exige qu'une contiguïté simple;

Attendu que l'immeuble connu sous le nom le Mens House" ne peut pas être envisagé comme urbain, dans le sens légal de ce mot, ni qu'il togobe d'une part au désert et d'autre part de vastes terrains de altore, soumis à les inondations périodiques; Qie la loi tient en effet pour urbains, les immeubles (constructions on terrains sitae, dans une agglomération batio (ville ou village), par opposition aux immeubles ruraux, dont la destination générale ost la altare plutôt que la bâtisse, et dans les quels les constructions sont par suite plus on moins espacées ;

Que vainement les intimes se prévalent du tait que diverses constructions ne seraient élevées récemment sur la route qui mène da Caire I aq Mena House car, selon l'esprit de la loi si la destination qu'elle vise, n'est pay one destination éventuelle, hypothétique et partant plus ou moins incertaine on aléatoire: mais une destination résultant positivement et actuellement de fait que les immeubles (constructions on terrains) sont situés au milieu on dans le voisinage immédiat d'une agglomération bâtie.

Attenda d'entre part qu'en l'espèce les deux immeubles ont cessé depuis le 27 Novembre 1895 d'être unis par un lien de servitude, ia partie préemptée et son auteur ayant à oletta date renonce au bedfordi la servitude qui grevait le fonds du préempteur au bénéfice du fonds préempté.

Que vainement les intimés prétendent un droit aoq pis qui serait résulté d'une déclaration de préemption antérieure à la renonciation, or il est de droit commun, que les servitudes sé toïgo ont par la renonciation de propriétaire de l'héritage dominant et que la renonciation n'a pas besoin d'être acceptée pour produire re effets entre les parties (Aubry et Rau T. III 965 poto 31); et d'autre part, selon une règle régissant particulièrement la manière de la perception," la propriété de l'immeuble sur lequel " le droit de préemption est exercé ne s'ap " quet au préempteur que par la décision du "juge ou par la livraison qui lui on est faite volontairement par l'aube tour" (Kadry Pa cha, Statut réel, selon le rite Hanafite. art. 125,

Qu'en somme aucune raison de droit on d'équité de s'opposer à ce qu'on puisse se prémunir, en renonçant au bénéfice d'une servitude, atre les suites få sableuses d'une préemption, i, a raison de son caractère exorbitant, doit e strictement maintenue dans ses limites rales,
Qu'en l'espèce, la servitude étant légalement binte, la préemption n'a plus aucune raison Btre et la demande doit donc être rejetée môme manquant d'une base légale.

Déboute les intimes de la demande en préemption introduite à leur requête par l'exploit récité da 11 Novembre 1905, et les condamne aux dépens de Ire instance et d'appel, tant vis-à-vis de la société appelante que vis à vis 88 époux Locke King.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.

div.head: LIDO (VENICE) LIDO
div.p: From Vernon or Lido, 12 min by steamboat. Climatic Station and Sea Baths, with Chinesitherapic Institute. Express between the station and Lido for the hotels.

div.head: BAGNI LIDO
div.p: The most important bathing station in Italy. ____ Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic institute. Concerts daily, frequented by the highest classes of society.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: St. Moritz (Engadine) Switzerland. The Grand Hotel St. Moritz.
div.p: A new first class hotel with every modern convenience.
Address all inquiries to THE MANAGER.

div.head: LAKE OF COMO (Cernobble.) GRAND HOTEL VILLA D'ESTE
div.p: First-class hotel, finest situation on the Lake. Immense park and garden. Moderate charges. Omnibus at Como station.

div.head: COMO "PLINIUS" GRAND HOTEL,
div.p: On the border of the Lake with beautfiul Garden and large Terraces. Magnificent Palace, built for the purpose of an Hotel, with the most complete comfort. Opened March, 1899. Very reasonable prices. English church.
Proprietor: J. De Glacomi, Manager of Gd. Hotel Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz, Engadine, Switzerland.
Manager: C. Scrobbi, of Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz.

div.head: LUGANO (Lake of Lugane) GRAND HOTEL METROPOLE ET MONOPOLE.
div.p: Also of the GRAND HOTEL, LUGANO.

div.head: LOCARNO THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: Strictly first class. Every modern comfort. Terminus of the St. Gothard Railway. Magnificent winter and spring Resort. Best stopping place on the Italian lakes. Beautiful walks excursion English Chruch. Tennis and Golf. Central Heating.

div.head: LUCERNE HOTEL DE L'EUROPE
div.p: Comfortable family hotel, charmingly situated, known for its quietness, Extensive view of Lake and Mountain scenery. Newly furnished, every modern comfort, lift, electric light, throughout, grand hall and covered terraces, beautiful garden, table d'Hotel at small tables, moderate terms.

div.head: INNSBRUCK (Tyrol) CARL KAISER'S PENSION-HOTEL
div.p: Splendid situation, overlooking river and valley, surrounded by fruit, conifer and rose gardens, modern comforts and home-like, Library, English and American papers, baths, carriages, good Table and sanitary arrangements.

Specially suitable for those requiring rest, quietness, and change of air. Capital headquarters for excursions. Post telegraph, telephone, dark room, terms moderate for either short or long stay. English spoken. Apply for prospectus.

div.head: INTERLAKEN Regina Hotel,
div.p: Unrivalled position. FIRST CLASS. Thoroughly renovated suites and rooms with private baths.

div.head: CHATEAU D'OEX THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: The newesty and most up-to-date, thoroughly First Class and replete with every modern comfort.
ELECRTIC LIGHT, CENTRAL HEATING, PRIVATE BATHS.

div.head: HOTEL BERTHOD.
div.p: The most comfortable first class family hotel.

div.head: ATHENS HOTEL DE LA GRANDE BRETAGNE
div.p: Special Office in the Hotel for Railway and Steamship

div.head: TOURIST AGENCY. POLEMY BROS., ATHENS.
div.p: 2. Philellenic Street (corner of Constitution Square), Conducted Tours for visiting Greece, Ionian Islands, Islands of the Archipelago, Asia Minor, Turkey, Palestine and Egypt.

div.head: CORFU GRAND HOTEL D'ANGLETERRE ET BELLE VENISE
div.p: Only first-class Hotel in Corfu with magnificent Garden. Fashionable modern Family Hotel. View of the Sea and lovely landscapes. Quietest, healthiest, and highest situation. Is the only Hotel situation in the highest part of Corfu.
